On 30 January 1915, a charity match was organized in England, featuring a team comprised of sportsmen who were recruited to support Edgar Mobbs' World War I battalion. This match aimed to raise funds for Mobbs' cause. The commemorative event will take place on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club, where players from the East Midlands region will face the 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, and Olney Ladies will challenge the Army Women's XV. Mobbs was born in Northampton in 1882, and he went on to become a captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907. He was selected for England in 1909 and scored a try on his debut against Australia. Mobbs served in the military during WWI, rising from a private to a battalion commander. He fought in various battles, including Loos, the Somme, Arras, and Messines, and was awarded the Distinguished Service Order. Tragically, he lost his life while charging a German machine gun during the Battle of Passchendaele on 31 July.

The CSCS (Construction Skills Certification Scheme) card is a crucial requirement for construction workers in the UK, demonstrating their skills and knowledge of health and safety. However, a joint BBC London/Newsnight investigation uncovered widespread cheating in the certification process. Carl Rhymer of the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB) revealed that 6,000 cardholders would need to retake the exam. The CSCS card is widely recognized as the primary means of certifying builders in the UK and is required by several major construction companies, Crossrail, and Heathrow.  The investigation discovered numerous test centers offering guaranteed passes for cash, enabling workers with limited English proficiency to obtain qualifications and access potentially dangerous construction sites. During the investigation, the BBC exposed Wep HSE, an Ealing-based center, after its director, Garet Estensen, openly instructed candidates to follow him on screen as he shouted the correct answers. When confronted with the evidence, Mr. Estensen remained silent. Two other centers exposed during the investigation were Future Training 4. The findings of the investigation raise serious concerns about the integrity of the CSCS card and the safety of construction sites in the UK. The Construction Industry Training Board and other relevant authorities must take immediate action to address this issue, including strengthening oversight of test centers, implementing stricter penalties for cheating, and ensuring that all workers are held accountable for demonstrating their skills and knowledge of health and safety.
